speaker: IMOGEN
text_entry: SCENE III. Wales: a mountainous country with a cave.

speaker: IMOGEN
text_entry: Enter, from the cave, BELARIUS; GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS following

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: A goodly day not to keep house, with such

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Whose roof's as low as ours! Stoop, boys; this gate

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Instructs you how to adore the heavens and bows you

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: To a morning's holy office: the gates of monarchs

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Are arch'd so high that giants may jet through

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And keep their impious turbans on, without

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Good morrow to the sun. Hail, thou fair heaven!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: We house i' the rock, yet use thee not so hardly

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: As prouder livers do.

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: Hail, heaven!

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: Hail, heaven!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Now for our mountain sport: up to yond hill;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Your legs are young; I'll tread these flats. Consider,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: When you above perceive me like a crow,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: That it is place which lessens and sets off;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And you may then revolve what tales I have told you

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Of courts, of princes, of the tricks in war:

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: This service is not service, so being done,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: But being so allow'd: to apprehend thus,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Draws us a profit from all things we see;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And often, to our comfort, shall we find

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The sharded beetle in a safer hold

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Than is the full-wing'd eagle. O, this life

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Is nobler than attending for a cheque,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Richer than doing nothing for a bauble,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Prouder than rustling in unpaid-for silk:

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Such gain the cap of him that makes 'em fine,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Yet keeps his book uncross'd: no life to ours.

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: Out of your proof you speak: we, poor unfledged,

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: Have never wing'd from view o' the nest, nor know not

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: What air's from home. Haply this life is best,

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: If quiet life be best; sweeter to you

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: That have a sharper known; well corresponding

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: With your stiff age: but unto us it is

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: A cell of ignorance; travelling a-bed;

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: A prison for a debtor, that not dares

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: To stride a limit.

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: What should we speak of

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: When we are old as you? when we shall hear

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: The rain and wind beat dark December, how,

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: In this our pinching cave, shall we discourse

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: The freezing hours away? We have seen nothing;

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: We are beastly, subtle as the fox for prey,

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: Like warlike as the wolf for what we eat;

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: Our valour is to chase what flies; our cage

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: We make a quire, as doth the prison'd bird,

speaker: ARVIRAGUS
text_entry: And sing our bondage freely.

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: How you speak!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Did you but know the city's usuries

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And felt them knowingly; the art o' the court

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: As hard to leave as keep; whose top to climb

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Is certain falling, or so slippery that

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The fear's as bad as falling; the toil o' the war,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: A pain that only seems to seek out danger

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: I' the name of fame and honour; which dies i'

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: the search,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And hath as oft a slanderous epitaph

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: As record of fair act; nay, many times,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Doth ill deserve by doing well; what's worse,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Must court'sy at the censure:--O boys, this story

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The world may read in me: my body's mark'd

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: With Roman swords, and my report was once

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: First with the best of note: Cymbeline loved me,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And when a soldier was the theme, my name

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Was not far off: then was I as a tree

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Whose boughs did bend with fruit: but in one night,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: A storm or robbery, call it what you will,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Shook down my mellow hangings, nay, my leaves,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And left me bare to weather.

speaker: GUIDERIUS
text_entry: Uncertain favour!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: My fault being nothing--as I have told you oft--

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: But that two villains, whose false oaths prevail'd

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Before my perfect honour, swore to Cymbeline

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: I was confederate with the Romans: so

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Follow'd my banishment, and this twenty years

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: This rock and these demesnes have been my world;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Where I have lived at honest freedom, paid

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: More pious debts to heaven than in all

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The fore-end of my time. But up to the mountains!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: This is not hunters' language: he that strikes

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The venison first shall be the lord o' the feast;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: To him the other two shall minister;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And we will fear no poison, which attends

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: In place of greater state. I'll meet you in the valleys.

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Exeunt GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: How hard it is to hide the sparks of nature!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: These boys know little they are sons to the king;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Nor Cymbeline dreams that they are alive.

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: They think they are mine; and though train'd

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: up thus meanly

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: I' the cave wherein they bow, their thoughts do hit

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The roofs of palaces, and nature prompts them

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: In simple and low things to prince it much

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Beyond the trick of others. This Polydore,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The heir of Cymbeline and Britain, who

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The king his father call'd Guiderius,--Jove!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: When on my three-foot stool I sit and tell

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The warlike feats I have done, his spirits fly out

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Into my story: say 'Thus, mine enemy fell,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And thus I set my foot on 's neck;' even then

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: The princely blood flows in his cheek, he sweats,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Strains his young nerves and puts himself in posture

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: That acts my words. The younger brother, Cadwal,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Once Arviragus, in as like a figure,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Strikes life into my speech and shows much more

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: His own conceiving.--Hark, the game is roused!

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: O Cymbeline! heaven and my conscience knows

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Thou didst unjustly banish me: whereon,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: At three and two years old, I stole these babes;

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Thinking to bar thee of succession, as

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Thou reft'st me of my lands. Euriphile,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Thou wast their nurse; they took thee for

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: their mother,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: And every day do honour to her grave:

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Myself, Belarius, that am Morgan call'd,

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: They take for natural father. The game is up.

speaker: BELARIUS
text_entry: Exit
